objtitle.title: *The Body of Edward I in His Coffin, Two Rough Drawings*

objdescid.origination: anonymousSome of the inscriptions, such as the roman numerals above each image and the measurements above and on the left side of the left image may have been inscribed by someone other than Blake. delineator
objdescid.compdate: 1774The design shows the body of King Edward I when his coffin was opened on 2 May 1774.

objinfo.objsize: 20.0 x 14.3 cm.Each of the two individual drawings on this leaf are approximately 16.5 x 5.5 cm.
objinfo.medium: pen and ink and pencilThe major lines in the design are in pen and ink, some over pencil. Some shading and interior lines are in pencil, as are the measurements above and on the left side of the image on the left. All other inscriptions are in pen and ink. The collection mark of the Society of Antiquaries, stamped in black ink, appears bottom right.
objinfo.support: laid paperThe drawing is pasted to a backing leaf of blue-gray paper, inscribed below the drawing "EDWARD I." in pen and ink and, lower right in pencil, "William Blake" following by two undecipherable words on a second line. These mount inscriptions are not by Blake.
objinfo.pennednumbers: "I" and "II"These numbers appear above each image. They do not represent a sequence of drawings.
objinfo.framelines: noneThere are no frame lines on the drawing itself, but a single frame line in pen and ink appears on the backing leaf.

provenance.name: Society of Antiquaries, London
provenance.note: The Society of Antiquaries commissioned Blake's engraving master, James Basire, to execute this drawing. Basire assigned Blake to this task. The drawing was presumably delivered to the Society shortly after its execution.

desc.objtitle:
The Body of Edward I in His Coffin, Two Rough Drawings,
object 1 (Butlin 1)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The Body of King Edward I lying in his coffin is shown in two views. Shadows (or perhaps fabric lining the coffin?) darken the area around the figures' head and shoulders. The figure wears a crown and holds a scepter in his left hand in both views. The figure at left is more heavily draped with a shroud that covers his face. The features and accoutrements of the figure at right are visible in greater, though still indistinct, detail. These include closed eyes, a nose, mouth, and short hair. Both hands hold scepters in the right view, the left topped with an indistinguishable form and the right in the shape of a cross. Both feet are visible. The inscriptions above the views identify both bodies as Edward I, the left as he "appeard on first opening the Coffin" and the right "when some of the vestmen/ were remov'd-" (see the Textual Transcription, lines 2, 5-6).

component.illusobjdesc: The Body of King Edward I lying in his coffin is shown in two views. The figure at left wears a crown and holds a scepter in his left hand. A shroud covers his face and body. The inscription above this view identifies the figure as Edward I, as he "appeard on first opening the Coffin" (lines 2).

The Body of King Edward I lying in his coffin is shown in two views. The figure at right, though still presumably shrouded, is less heavily draped than in the view on the left. His features and accoutrements are visible in greater, though still indistinct, detail. These include closed eyes, a nose, mouth, and short hair. He wears a crown and both hands hold scepters, the left topped with an indistinguishable form and the right in the shape of a cross. Both feet are visible. The inscription above this view identifies the figure as Edward I, "when some of the vestmen/ were remov'd-" (lines 5-6).
The bodies of two dead figures, presumably male, lie in open coffins.
Shadows (or perhaps fabric lining the coffins?) darken the area around the figures' head and shoulders.

lg.l: The body of Edward ye 1st as it
appeard on first opening the Coffin.
IThis inscription may not be by Blake.
2-7This inscription in pencil is written upside down just above the top of the left coffin, for which it may be a measurement. It may not be by Blake.
6-7This inscription in pencil is written vertically (read top to bottom) to the left of the left coffin, for which it may be a measurement. It may not be by Blake.
2-3This inscription in pencil is written upside down across the middle of the left coffin, for which it may be a measurement. It may not be by Blake.

3This inscription in pencil is written upside down within the left wall of the left coffin approximately three-quarters of the way down the leaf. It is likely a measurement for the width of the coffin's walls. It may not be by Blake.

1-10This inscription in pencil is written upside down jut above the bottom edge of the left coffin, for which it may be a measurement. It may not be by Blake. To the left of this inscription are some pencil marks that may include the letter "V", but this is uncertain.
IIThis inscription may not be by Blake.
